Judul: The carnivalesque, parody and irony in the  contemporary american visual art: Project  Womanhouse, a case study
Abstrak:
The  present  paper  situates  its  concerns  at  the  crossroads  of  Gender  Studies,  visual  art  and 
feminist  theories  in  its  attempt  at  investigating  an  (in)famous  1972  art  installation  by 
American  artists  Judy  Chicago  and  Miriam  Shapiro,  Project  Womanhouse.  Primarily grounded on contemporary theories of gender as a cultural construct, this study is concerned with  how  this  particular  instance  of  the  contemporary  American  visual  arts  deals  with  the deconstruction  and  reconstruction  of  gender  through parody  and  irony.  The  study  also discusses  the  problematic  viewpoint  of  feminism  on gender  as  too  narrow-sighted  and restrictive,  while  opting  for  the  term  feminine  to describe  the  gender-related  statements  of the artists under scrutiny.
